commentBody: Every time one of my students asks if they can go to the bathroom I give them 37 across.
Kelvin and I are so not on same wave length. But enjoyable puzzle.

Deb,
9D? How soon you forget! [Plan B, for seniors] is where you go when you don't get into your first choice college.

It took me a while to get onto Kelvin's wavelength. 
That's a good thing. I like a puzzling puzzle. 
Happy Friday [puzzle]!

Nice one, Kelvin.
Very happy with that. I’m excited to do well but my time being a minute more than my average was just fine given how tricky those clues were. And wild new words too. Great new constructor!

To me, this is the ideal Friday, with plenty of chewy clues that when properly chewed educe a smile from the wordplay. Thanks Kelvin!

For 37A, I was under the impression that the answer shouldn’t contain any of the words from the clue. Am I mistaken in that?
How is Houston a port?

Well, just this afternoon, I explained in the Thursday comments that a word in one clue and the same word in a different clue's answer is fine; just the same word in one clue and answer pair isn't.

And then we get 37A.

I was going to put I DON'T KNOW BUT YOU MAY, but it didn't fit.

Overall, this was a very tough one.  I had missing letters all over, and I got that once-in-a-while feeling that maybe, just maybe, I'd be stuck for a while.

Well, everything cleared up eventually, and I got my gold star.

Some observations:

An [Apple product] on Fri. or Sat. is probably related to fruit, not technology.

A [Small songbird] is a WREN when it's four letters, and 54A when it's three.  Always.

EDUCE and "evoke" both work at 14A; SKIRTS could also be "evades" or "avoids" if you don't have any crosses yet.

Abbreviated musical keys in four letters are something MAJ or something MIN; the something can be A-G.

ADIEU and "adios" were another kealoa.

A five-letter [Silly one] is always a GOOSE.  A three-letter [Silly one] is a donkey-like beast.

ERIKA, ROYCE, KLEIN, and ROEG were all unknowns to me, and they were all in the SW quadrant.

In 9D, "seniors" aren't old folks, and Plan B isn't Medicare. In 3D, "characters" aren't persons in the story. In 10D, "server loads" has nothing to do with big computers.  These are some of the things to look out for on a tough Friday, which probably should have been a Saturday.  (Xwordstats.com calls it "Very Hard.")

These are some of the things to look out for on a tough Friday, which probably should have been a Saturday. (Xwordstats.com calls it "Very Hard.")
The STICKER SHOCK is so real these days.
Exceptional puzzle with lots of humor. Congratulations on your debut! Please make more!
I assumed right away the apple product was related to food, but I had CORER for a while. As for ETHER, I was sure I had something wrong until I saw the explanation in this column.

Speaking as a dermatologist, ECZEMA and atopic dermatitis are not synonymous!  Atopic dermatitis is a type of eczema, but it's not the only type.  This is like cluing REPTILES as "animals formally known as snakes."

I'm also not crazy about cluing ETHER as a "number."  I guess it depends on what your definition of a numbing agent, but most people would use that term to mean a local anesthetic like lidocaine, which makes your surgical site numb but you're still awake.  ETHER knocks you out and makes you unconscious.  I guess an unconscious person is numb, but that's an atypical way of thinking about that term IMO.
I’m usually hopeless when it comes to classical music key signatures, but today I confidently entered _MAJ for 24A, as Vivaldi’s Spring would sound quite different in a minor key…

I found this one to be a worthy challenge! One of those I wasn’t sure I would finish until I did. Thank you!

Related to 3D,  I have a question for those who have read LOTR (after 5 decades I am finally now reading it): will I miss anything important if I skip over all the terrain and scenery descriptions? It feels overdone but maybe it’s just me.
17A crossed with 3D is a nattick. Sad, because it was an otherwise fun puzzle.

Loved this Friday puzzle. First of all it was no pushover for me. But especially, there were So. Many. tricky clues with cleverly deceptive wordplay that made me chuckle aquiet. Looking forward to more puzzles from Kevin Zhou!

Congratulations on the debut, Kelvin, it was a tough puzzle! Years of snarky replies got me the grid spanner at 37A with very few crossings, which helped me maneuver around into some largely empty quadrants.  Well above average solve time for Friday for me, but a satisfying victory at the end. Thanks!

Been a while since I was in a math class, but fairly certain COS is not a derivative of sine. It’s not even possible to definitively determine the cosine knowing just the sine (e.g. if sin = 0 then cos can equal 1 or -1).  Csc would be the more appropriate answer here. 

However, if anyone more math-y than I can show I’m misguided, I’m happy to learn something new.

"Did you talk to your tailor about your missing garment?"
"Yeah, but he skirted the issue."

("He'll have to re-dress the situation.")

What a gem of a puzzle.  A high percentage of the clues involved at least some misdirection or trickery, but all were fair play. As someone often accused of being sarcastic, I got IDONTKNOWCANYOU right off the bat without any crosses and that big foothold in the middle really opened up the puzzle for me.  LOTR and Wire clues  were welcome gimmes.  For the tricky clues, my faves were PARACHUTE for opener for an aerial act and ARTFORGER for synthetic oil producer.  

I needed lots of crosses to get TCHOTCHKE.  That opening TCH created all kinds of uncertainty about whether the seemingly easy downs were correct. Just a really nice Friday puzzle.  -
Loved this puzzle, a lot of the clues made sense to me straight off the bat. Although, a safety school is not driving school, it’s the backup plan for when you don’t get your top choice of college!
Nice to have a themeless under my belt again after not being able to finish that brutal Saturday puzzle last weekend. Thanks for the nice debut Kelvin!
I think there is a better interpretation of 9D then Deb’s - ‘SAFETYSCHOOL’ refers to high school senior’s second choice in colleges
Surely a SAFETY SCHOOL is a high school senior's second-choice college which is easier to be accepted into, a "plan B" if they don't get accepted into their first choice school.
Second Wednesday in a row with a Sunday caliber clue list. A slog. Not fun today!

This was a great puzzle. I couldn't finish it -- parachute and art forgers eluded me in the NE and while I had almost all the crosses correct in the SW I couldn't detect the bobbleheaded tchotchke lurking within. Tough but fair, even though I'm not entirely sold on the clue for ether.

I just recently started trying to tackle the Thursday through Saturday puzzles (I let myself Google if I need to, otherwise I'd seldom finish them).  I think this might be the hardest puzzle I've ever attempted.  Wow!  Extremely clever clues, but beyond my poor brain.

All these wonderful debuts and I fall for 11D’s cluing (“Throw, maybe”). I had R_G and still got it wrong despite my high confidence. Sometimes the trickiest clues are the sneaky ones that only apply to some solvers depending on what other letters they’re already working with. 

As 60A famously said, “Sheeeeeeeeee…”
Too convoluted to finish.

The use of “number” in late week puzzles should always set off alarm bells when it doesn’t seem to work in its usual sense.  Another classic clue is “Number of people”, for which the answer is DENTIST.

A lot of pitfalls here, but on the end, a Gold Star after 37 minutes. NATTERON and its crossings were basically a Hail Mary in the end. I knew there is something in Massachusetts called the Ether Dome, which is the first place that ether was publicly used as a general anesthesia, so I didn't think they Ether was discovered in the 1500s. I know the word tchotchke, but not how to spell it.

Any LOTR clue is usually a gimme, but it took me a while to realize character meant symbol, and I also had cidER in 1A for a while.

11D I had RiG and thought it was particularly timely given this morning's news...

Man, that really got me. Hats off to Mr Zhou.

I know the term "safety school" as the college you apply to that isn't your top choice but that you feel confident you'll get into. So if all else fails you'll still have one school you can attend

Congratulations on your NYT debut, Mr. Zhou! 

There was enough tricky clueing that I had to work a little harder than on a Friday puzzle in recent memory, especially with the NE corner. I'd have done better if SAFETY SCHOOL hadn't taken so long come to me. I'm not term was in popular usage when I started college almost 50 years ago.

Hope we'll see you back here soon!
Good puzzle, not baht at all.  The derivative of sin could be the last judgement, and while a natterer may nay say, surely those who can cancan can.

Oh man that was great. Number was a good one!! I like puzzles like this that are made up of a collection of little riddles that each take a few minutes to suss out. However if they each take me more than 10 or 15 minutes then I get cranky (like last Saturday Lol). I guess we all have our point when we go from "yay this is fun" to cranky. Luckily for me this one was in my sweet spot 😊

Thank you for a wonderful puzzle!  I found it tough (almost 20 minutes over my average) but that was due to all the wonderfully clever misdirects. I don’t think any of them were too obscure or otherwise unfair. 
I was almost ready to start using Google when I had less than a quarter of the grid filled but I chipped away and chipped away until it all came together.  
This is my favourite type of puzzle.
This was some superior cluing! Super impressed!! I loved it!
Hardest Friday in recent memory, and I mean that as a complement!
More like this please

"How common is the noun lash-up?"
"Fewer than 0.01 occurrences per million words in modern written English" OED

The cluing really slowed me down for this one. Finished, but well over my average Friday time. 

Gotta laugh at myself for how long I had beauTYSCHOOL as a “Plan B, for seniors” — I thought it was awfully rude to the many amazing beauticians for whom that was plan A, but I figured it was influenced by Grease. Yes, that song is now in your head, sorry. 

Some of the clues don’t quite fit for me, though:
- a PARER is a product that is *for* apples; it’s a real stretch to clue that as “Apple product”
- in my experience, a RUG is never referred to as a “throw”. “Throw rug,” yes, but never just a “throw.”
- I can’t make sense of “Returns home?” as the clue for IRS — isn’t it missing an apostrophe after “Returns”?

Didn’t mean to NATTERON, just didn’t want to SKIRT the issue.

I had that wonderful feeling again of no way, no how will I get this puzzle.  30 minutes in wanted to concede defeat.

But in the west… had MIRAGE, then guessed ADIEU, then LAP, then LIMBO, then OUST… and a slow steady solve came out of nowhere.  71 minutes, one lookup to spell TCHOTCHKE.  I came so close to looking up the movie/tv names.  Just barely didn’t.  All unfamiliar to me.  And I do much wanted 9% of the Earth’s surface to be land.  Maybe true in the southern hemisphere alone.

Thanks terrific experience, again.  This puzzle had the magic of crosswords through and through.
A lot of misses for me personally this time. If someone asked me on the street I'd bet a hundred bucks NATTERED ON isn't a real word but here we are. Thanks for saving me a hundo!
Congratulations on your debut, Kelvin!  That was quite a workout. IDONTKNOWCANYOU made me laugh out loud. Shout out to Wesley for his NYT debut!
Pretty cool! took me too long to get 3D - I suspected RUNES from the start, but had PARER misspelled.

Listening to the game, I took my time, leisurely drifting around the puzzle, finally noticed that I had about four fills.  I asked myself, can I solve this puzzle?  Answer: I DONT KNOW, CAN YOU? It may be ETHER the puzzle or the game. 

Made some headway at halftime, then back to try again for the MIRAGE of two minds, but it looked like I was going to have to MARY I or the other, and decided to GO SOLO, went for the puzzle, and it was just as well.  I managed to finish it, went back to the game, which went into overtime, and the Dubs won it!  OH YES, it was the best of both worlds.

Kelvin Zhou, this was a heck of a debut puzzle.  I kept praying there wouldn't be any rebuses to make even harder than it was. Debut or the work of an old pro, it was a beauty. Thank you for a game that was as exciting as the other one.

Finally, a chewy, nougaty Friday. I wondered as I solved whether the puzzle’s texture was due to my not being fully awake yet, but judging from the comments, others got a bit of a workout, too. 

IDON’TKNOWCANYOU was a no-brainer with just the I in place, and so I have to whin… er… say: “Mom, CAN I (heh…) please get you out of my head? It’s 6am!” 

PARACHUTE and ARTFORGER, both brilliantly clued, offered some welcome pushback, as did—six-a.m.-edly perhaps—SKATEPARK which my brain stubbornly tried to make into something riparian, despite having almost all the crosses in place. 

It was nice to see RUNES not clued as divination tools. One day my dream  will come true and a clue for RUNES will be written in Elder Futhark characters. Okay, maybe not. But maybe a MIRAGE will call for 11 letters in lieu of 6 and turn out to be Fata Morgana, a term I picked up in an adventure novel as a kid possessed of the dream to see the Sahara one day. Having now seen the Sahara, I have yet to see that eerie illusion where the sand meets the sky, so the romantic dream lives on in its new grid form, sans the camels. Oy, the camels. But that’s a story for another day. 

The final bit of resistance came from ETHER. Although, as with the Saharan mirage, I’m not speaking from direct experience, there’s nothing numbing about ether’s effect on the body or the mind, so I needed all the crosses to fill it in. But that’s a tiny nit because there was so much to love in Kelvin’s puzzle. 

Saturday awaits…
Hey, Deb. I think safety school actually is referring to a college that is a backup if you don’t get into one of your first choices. i.e. “plan B”
Curious— “number” as in grapheme of an amount and “number” as in more numb are not homo”phones” since they differ in phonemes (num-mer vs num-ber). What is the correct term?
A Friday that felt like a Saturday. Challenging, fair, and fun. I’m amazed that it was a debut. Bravo!

Regarding the notes on the clues - "Safety School" actually refers to a back-up college or university with more lenient admissions than a student's desired college. For example, if your GPA is 3.7 you would aim for colleges competitive in that range, but just in case, you might also apply to a "safety school" with an average applicant GPA of 2.8 or so. 

Great puzzle, enjoyed the clue about the Number.

I frequently mention that I work on the crossword with my extended family. I rarely mention my wife because she is simultaneously solving the Spelling Bee and does not like to be interrupted. Me. “Sweetie, I need a four letter word for a cookie. First three letters are ORE…”  Her. “Dunno.”

But, tonight I am doing the puzzle and she is half asleep. Seventeen years of nursing experience kicked in and she mumbled “STETHO” just as she fell asleep.

Wow, absolutely fantastic debut. So many wonderful misdirects and clever clues, I can’t even list them all, but this was a straight up challenge and I had to jump all over the place. My favorite was ARTFORGER with RUNES close behind. Was looking for either baseball, kids games or digital pictures for the tag reference but it was none of those. Couldn’t fit EMERGENCY CONTRACEPTIVE in the Plan B space. I agree with Steve L the repeat of CAN in the center clue was jarring but somehow it works and I really the only way to clue this fresh entry.
One plea—I know you can’t always read every comment, and we can certainly expect duplicate opinions, complaints, observations etc.—but if you see an obvious error by the columnist (like Plan B today), maybe just skim to see if it was brought up before? First to call it out gets a gold star but after awhile it just gets annoying.
Some of the answers were fun but others that are dependent on knowing an obscure names (Roeg? Koen? Panza?) make the puzzle impossible to solve if you don't know them.

Deb, a "safety school" is that college you're pretty sure you'll get into. Normally something like the local state university with high admission rates, or the place where your parents went, or the one that offered an early scholarship based on SAT scores, etc. As compared to a "reach school" -- the Harvards of the world.
Well, now I know that TCHKE *can* be the end of a word. We live and learn.

🤣😂 This puzzle destroyed me. I did so badly it was actually quite funny 😃 On my own - and with much effort and guesswork - I was able to deal with a wedge running West and North West from the center of the grid. Elsewhere I was able to solve only a handful of clues, which did not give me enough crosses to do much more. After nearly 30 minutes of trying to make unaided progress, I looked up most of the trivia (I mean, I don't even know what Vox is, other than a European music TV channel, which clearly was not meant here today; also... YER?! Ye gods! And there was more of such arcana for me). That helped. I completed 3/4 of the grid then. Still, I needed reveals to handle the NE corner. (SAFETY) SCHOOL was completely alien to me, and I truly hated the clue for ART FORGER - there is nothing synthetic about works of art forgers, is there? They may be fake, but they are not synthetic. I get misdirection, but the price for it can't be resorting to falsehoods and abandoning sense. This was the only element of the puzzle I not only failed on but really disliked. I just was not on the constructor's wavelength, at all. The puzzle was probably fine, but I was not 🤣 And now for something completely different - Lucek in the forest: https://imgur.com/a/rTdFn9R
my cerebral cortices, yes both sides, are saddle sore after that ride.
I can't believe I solved this one. Most challenging Friday in a long time.

This was a tough challenge and satisfying solve for me. Many mistakes made along the way. For 10 Down,, I quickly wrote in Nitrogen which is in the second row on the right side of the periodic table, albeit not the far right. That ,however, led me nowhere.
I thought a clue could never contain a word in the answer for that clue.

Good morning. As a Brit, I feel it is my duty to point out that a LASH UP is, invariably these days, a very drunken party or night out with ‘the boys’. As in, “ how was that party last night, mate “? - “it was a massive lash-up, you missed a belter” ! OR “anyone fancy coming round to mine for a bit of a lash up”?
I thought the clueing was a just little too cute.
Never heard of Yer Blues, and I thought the Beatles song would be a gimme.    I liked this one in spite of, or maybe because of all the weird and wild misdirections.
isn't a safety school the opposite of a reach school (ie applying to harvard vs. applying to the local A&M or whatever)

Oh, Kevi Zhou, I bow before your constructing prowess. 

So, so many erasures!  cidER for PARER, StATE PARKS for SKATE PARKS, STErnO for STETHO, RiG for RUG...

This was tough for all the right reasons.  The cluing was fantastic, and the stickiest ones, like [Synthetic oil producer?]  for ART FORGER, yielded the good kind of groan.

Hopefully, your life will give you much opportunity to continue to make puzzles for us.  I'm anxiously awaiting your return.
Wow wow wow. Absolutely loved the misdirections but they all made sense in hindsight. I didn’t get a toehold until the middle of the grid. I really earned this solve. Whew!

I often do a quick pass through the clues on Friday and Saturday puzzles to enter in any gimmes. The most satisfying puzzles, in my opinion, are the ones that are mostly blank after the first pass before they slowly and steadily fall into place, like this puzzle.  Enjoyable! Thanks!

Great puzzle and satisfying to solve. Took me some time to get a toe hold. BAHT of all things being my first gimme after descending the diagonal of short words. 
Liked the clue for STICKER SHOCK. I needed lots of crosses as I was thinking along the lines of Baseball tags or school yard tags. I had my aha moment and told my daughter the clue as she walked past feeling pretty pleased with myself but she immediately got it! 
ART FORGER crossing SAFETY SCHOOL was my final entry. 
This felt like a Saturday difficulty and definitely took me longer than usual for a Friday. 
Congrats Kelvin on your debut! I enjoyed your funny note. How fortunate we used to be to have universities and scientific institutions that attracted people like you from all over the world that enriched our society or at the very least went home to enrich theirs and spread good will to the USA. We’re going to miss that.

I love all the many wordplay features in the clues, once I finally got them.
I was lucky to get the marquee answer on my first pass through so I had a good few crossing letters to hang words on. Even still, this was a tough solve.
I was sure the number discovered was Euler's number, e, and I even saw the possible double-meaning way before I realised I was wrong. And PANZA in the top left was a certainty, but left me completely stumped on the first three down crossings.
Other favourite wordplay clues are Returns home? for IRS, Starting line at a starting line, and Characters in LOTR.

Congratulations on your debut NYT puzzle! It had me going for a bit. The first clue I cracked was “I Don’t Know Can You.” As a retired English professor (and a current Mom/Aunt), I was delighted! Clever clues all around. I hope to see more of your puzzles. I’ll be looking for you!

Superb! It took me ages to wrestle this one to the ground and I loved every minute, especially those things Deb was complaining about 😁 known as misdirects. ARTFORGER alone was worth the price of admission. And how many constructors have what it takes to get TCHOCHKES into a puzzle? Seven consonants, three of them where you don't normally expect them, to two vowels, and a fun word at that.

Come back and see us again soon, Mr. Zhou.

Don't know if the constructor ever heard of the alternate and equally (or possibly more) snarky parent/teacher response: 
You CAN if you are ABLE.

So, I know I CAN, but also MAY I say that the constructor notes for this puzzle are as uplifting as solving the puzzle itself?
This was really hard for me, a great debut! Lovely to hear more about Kelvin in his constructor notes too :)

Regarding 37A, I’m sure longtime solvers are very familiar with Margaret Farrar. Newer solvers may not be but her story is pretty fascinating and Wikipedia has an excellent article about her. It seems that early crosswords were kind of a mess. She was committed to improving the quality of crossword puzzles and compiled many of the guidelines about construction and format. And this was years before she became the first editor of the NYTXW. 

I don’t know if Mrs. Farrar came up with the rule prohibiting the use of the same word both in a clue and in its answer but I think she would approve of the breach here since this is a very fine puzzle.
15 minutes over my average for a Friday, but super-proud of myself!  A toughie.

Congratulations on your debut, Kelvin! And another shoutout to Wesley.

TGIF

Fantastic debut.

Fantastic constructor notes.

Wesley is officially famous.

Well done!
Annoying, then wonderfully challenging. What a Friday treat!

Oh yes.  “Mwah!” squared.  Pinnacle puzzle.  What I hope for.

Where when I look at the finished grid, there is hardly an unknown word, but to get from the blank grid to that finished grid, you have to get through a barricade of riddles.  Where the brain has to go sideways, has to imagine, has to explore for treasure.  Where pings of pleasure await, one after another.

Where the puzzle is not a test of knowledge, but a workout (sweat) and a work-out (unravel mysteries).  Where wordplay reigns.  I marked 15 clues as special – the highest, I believe, I’ve ever marked for a puzzle this size.

There is talent behind the making of this, and when the constructor indicates in his notes that he is working on more – well, that is most exciting to me.

More, please, Kelvin, and more like this dazzling debut, please.  I loved this.  Thank you, sir!

Loved solving this one, delightfully tricky.

But I was thrown off a little by 37a - isn't it against the crossword rules if the answer repeats a word in the clue?

Wow! What a wonderful debut puzzle! A perfect Friday. Excellent cluing for delightful answers. Took longer than my average but lots of fun! I had TYPINGPOOL for a long time. Then took it all out only to have pool again. 🤦🏻‍♀️ when I realized it was STENO. Thanks for a great debut, Kelvin. Y’all have a fantastic Friday!
Mea culpa.  I found this puzzle way too tough. If people like chewy puzzles, this one was STRINGY!

Deb, I think you got the meaning of SAFETYSCHOOL wrong. Per my AI bot:

A "safety school" is a college or university where an applicant has a high probability of being accepted because their academic profile, such as GPA and test scores, is stronger than the average admitted student. These are considered more achievable options that provide a fallback in case an applicant is not accepted into their "reach" or "target" schools.

Take ALL the good things already said by others - I agree!

Not easy for me though because of not knowing the meaning of some clues:

STICKER SHOCK connected to 'tag' - absolutely no idea. I only know stickers as something children get for good work in school, or for them making pictures with different shapes. 

LASH UP - not known except as a wild party, (already mentioned) also "out on the lash".

STETHO as a prefix -  is that stethochest or cheststetho? Is that the same as stethoscope?

THREEPIN - went bowling 20 years ago, didn't score a single point, so didn't know numbers were involved.

SAFETY SCHOOL - obvious from crossers, fortunately. In the UK you apply centrally for up to 5 universities or courses.
Very impressive debut. And as far as 37 Across is concerned, the Pointer Sisters say Yes, We Can Can. https://youtu.be/IzZkjjENj_w?si=pFPAAThJRFjjbqT_

I'm usually the first of the few, if any, curmudgeons here who dislikes the barrage of debut constructors that have made the NYT famous for forcing their tried-and-true lineup of seasoned constructors to other sites. 

But I have to say that this is the first time in a long time that I smiled through most of this puzzle, thanks to the plethora of delightfully devious clues.

"Number" (ETHER) is an old one, but I found ART FORGER, PARACHUTE, I DON'T KNOW CAN YOU, SPINNING RING, STICKER SHOCK, and the prefix for Chest, which wasn't Sterno, but STETHO, so much fun. And there were a few more that were worthy of recognition.

Even more amusing was Kelvin's notes, which also gave me a few giggles. Our commenters here usually love to buoy up new constructors, saying they hope to see more of their puzzles soon. This is the very first time I'm throwing my own hat into that ring. Thanks, Kelvin!

This was great fun for a Friday.

From the very beginning, or close to it, I could see that he would be putting something tricky at every opportunity. TRAY, PARER, ETHER, IRS, and plenty more. 

RUNES--although I've lost count of how many times I've read LOTR, this was possibly the last to fall.

Not a single complaint from me. One of those days when you're filling in entries and the gold star catches you by surprise.

Thanks!

Struggled, which is say . . . Great puzzle! Even when I had some idea where the wordplay was going, either there were too many, um, variables; [Derivative of sin]-->five, three of which begin with C; or I couldn't think of a good synonym: [Plan B, for seniors]="back-up college," (sorry, Deb), but how would that be rephrased? Our lessons in music theory continue. Fellow (non-musician) Wordplayers, don't forget, second letter's always M. But let me share one of my all-time favorite New Yorker covers, which moves from the piano bench to the music stand every year, about Mar. 21: https://www.newyorker.com/culture/cover-story/cover-story-2018-04-16
The word that starts with an "H" and rhymes with deck will get your comment stuck in the emu's automated filter.  Seems a bit too strict.

Yeah, that was hard. Real hard. 

I liked it!
This was a Saturday level difficulty. I had to get some help.
Some of the best clue writing I’ve seen in a while.  Very witty and a fun Friday solve.

I enjoy a difficult puzzle… when it’s made difficult in a clever way. Too often the inclusion of too much trivia, niche answers and clues, and my personal bugaboo: misdirection that IMO “doesn’t quite work” results in a difficult puzzle that I find annoying rather than enjoyable.

But today’s puzzle!! Chef’s kiss. A++.  I’ve only been doing the puzzle for a few years now, but I have never come across one so chock full of fantastic misdirection. And by that I mean clues that look straightforward and aren’t obviously misleading, but when you figure out the answer and actual meaning of the clue, it works perfectly. Too often I come across clues where the constructor had a really clever idea for misdirection, but the result left me thinking “yeah, it kinda works, but ain’t great”

Today it was almost all pure gold. Hats off to Kelvin Zhou. Sure, I have a minor quibble or two. But man was this good!  The number (in the math sense 🤓) of times I got that feeling of exhilaration from figuring out the answer and appreciating the cleverness of the clue was off the charts.

And sure there were some proper names and trivia in there. There always is in a late week puzzle. But no more than usual (and probably less). 

More like this please!

I enjoy punny puzzles. This one left me cold. So many of the answers, for me, were rather "meh." Not half as clever as the constructor thought. B- Also ~25% of across clues were just straight up trivia. What the challenge there?
Excellent. Excellent.

Honestly, although this was no walk in the park, and I was tempted a few times to look something up (something I avoided today, thankfully), this is one of my favorite puzzles in quite a while. There are so many delightful clues: “Number” for ETHER; “Locales with many banks” for SKATE PARKS; “Characters in ‘The Lord of the Rings’” for RUNES; “Opener for an aerial act” for PARACHUTES; “Synthetic oil producer” for ART FORGER…I could go on, but I’ll stop there.  This was a smash of a debut, so congratulations to Kelvin Zhou.
Maybe just a little too-too.

Such a great puzzle!

Lots of the misdirects here are oldies-but-goodies (e.g. “spinning” with “PR”, “bolted” for “ATE”, “ECIG”), but they’re combined in a way that made this a very fun solve, somewhat reminiscent of last Saturday (IIRC).

Personal favorite: THREEPIN. “It’s on the right in the second row” is one of those clues that initially feels either impossibly vague or unreasonably specific (and in this case, perhaps even a meta reference to the contents of the grid itself), but then works perfectly once it has fallen into place.

More like this one, please!

My friend said she liked my last-second attempt at constructing a crossword puzzle. But she wasn’t fooling me with the faint praise,  it was a lash up: eye rolls, all make-shifty.

Whereas today’s puzzle: truly impressive!

Now that’s a puzzle!  Fresh fill, no glue, devilish misdirects!  Loved the long downs. By my count there were only 25 three and four letter words, which seems unusual to me.  Does anyone know the statistics on that?
These clues were evil. Loved it!

Going for a walk now to give my brain a rest!

I’d like to thank Don Gillis, former host of Candlepin Bowling Stars on Boston area television back in the 1960’s (I believe) for teaching me the location and numbers of the pins in bowling. Each week one of the players would try to convert the 1-7-10 split with no wood. It’s not impossible, but very difficult. If anyone could convert it, they won a cash prize. Also each week viewers would send in very difficult spare leads for the bowlers to attempt to convert. All of these were described by numbers. So thank you Don.

I’m about halfway through with the puzzle and I’m putting it aside for later. It’s too nice of a day out to give this any more of my time. But, a young buck caught our attention this morning. We looked outside our backyard windows and spotted a deer with newly-sprouted spikes, about 6” long. He was staring intently at our back deck area, where we heard some commotion earlier in the morning. The deck area is slightly recessed under the upper porch, therefore we couldn’t see what he was looking at. It turns out, he had chased a young doe, who made her refuge under the porch overhang, on our deck. Her hind end was pressed against the sliding glass doors, and she was soaking wet and trembling. It hadn’t rained all week, so maybe it was sweat, or morning dew, who knows. Fearful that she’d kick her hind legs through the glass, we just watched. She had a wound on her left shoulder, likely from struggling to escape the clutches of her suitor. We left it at that, they’ve gone their separate ways now. Poor doe. Mother nature; just leave her be. I was so glad to see Jesus made it into crosslandia, what a welcome sight! I took this photograph a few months ago while on our weekly Meals On Wheels delivery. https://imgur.com/a/cant-make-this-stuff-up-2aTR9qJ It’s rural Georgia, what can I say?

If you don’t subscribe to the NYT Easy Mode newsletter, you will miss some interesting comments about crosswords generally (usually from editor Christina Iverson).

I’ve sometimes copypasta’ed those comments here. I’m too lazy to do that today, because it usually takes three comments to do it all, and I get bored or distracted waiting for the first comment to post so I can write a second one. 

Anyway: Today’s Easy Mode newsletter has a great explanation of the number and quality of three-letter words that are acceptable in a NYT puzzle.

As a solver, I don’t like to see a lot of three-letter words in a grid. As a sometimes constructor, I know how important short words are in allowing you to construct a grid that you can actually fill. 

If the topic interests you, seek out the newsletter.

Circled back after I learned a few things about Michelangelo's "The Last Judgement." I was only vaguely familiar with the piece, but thought JESUS was too obvious an answer, so I went with JudaS. Nope, but King Minos does appear, as the judge of the underworld. First funny story: There was a Vatican official who was highly critical of all the nudity in the painting. Michelangelo responded by putting his face on Minos' body, complete with donkey ears. Second funny story: After the great master's death, one of his students was commanded to paint over all the naughty bits, which earned him the nickname,  "Il Braghettone," which means, "the trouser maker." One last story: The artist painted his own face on the flayed skin of Saint Bartholomew, which dangles precariously over the bad place. This has been interpreted as Michelangelo's not being quite sure about his immortal soul.

@Andrzej
Re. the clue for ART FORGERS: Yes, everything about forgery is, in fact, synthetic. One sense of synthetic is something that is ersatz, imitative, not genuine, just plain fake. The clue wasn’t using the word to mean it as something produced artificially or chemically.

@Andrzej
Look at Merriam-Webster’s definitions 4.b-c, especially c, where it’s given as a synonym for factitious, bogus. The sentence examples in M-W aren’t great, so here’s one from the OED, which is apt, albeit old: 

“He has been in London long enough to achieve a synthetic British appearance.”
1948 Newsweek 10 May 34/2

Don’t let the date on the cit. or the M-E definition’s being dead last lead you to believe this is a rare sense of the word: ‘synthetic’ meaning ‘chemically produced’ is 4.a(1)… ‘Synthetic’ has many meanings.

@Andrzej

Cognates are always the trickiest part of a second language. Neuronal pathways for a particular word are already set. 

Think of it this way:

Castrol is a producer of synthetic oil which is used as a substitute for petroleum-refined oils when operating in extreme temperatures (thank you, Wikipedia).  Here synthetic means ‘chemically produced.”

Elmyr de Hory produced hundreds of forged Picassos. These synthetic oils and drawings fetched millions on the art market. Here synthetic means ‘fake,’ ‘bogus,’ ‘imitation.’

@Sam Lyons

I've been thinking about this on my way home from work: imagine a largely leather-clad, mostly unshaven guy driving a slightly redneckish Mustang in heavy, cold rain, pondering the intricacies of language.

I realized, I think, my problem also had to do with defining art forgery:

1) If somebody ineptly tries to imitate a great artist's style - Sofonisba Anguissola's, say - and produces a new work, rather than a perfect copy of an existing one, then I get it, after your explanations, anyway: this new, imperfect work ala Anguissola is synthetic in the way you describe. It is fake, ersatz, nothing like the real deal.

2) However, if a master sculptor in their own right perfectly copies one of the versions of Rodin's Kiss or Thinker, or even creates a masterful, unique variant to continue Rodin's series - it's not ersatz, is it? Legally it is a forgery, if sold as the real deal, but artistically it is not, not really.

Where does this lead me? I think I see the light now, thanks to you, Sam. *Some* art forgeries may be considered synthetic, and that's enough for the clue to work.

I still hate it though 🤣

But I love this conversation.

@SP

Let's beat the poor dead horse some more (btw, you'd be surprised, probably, by what "to beat one's horse" means in Polish...)

You say what you do, but a forgery is *not* artificially made. It's made by a person using real media. Look at it this way: plastic, fake wood panelling is artificial and synthetic. It is not wood - chemically, it is plastic, a synthetic material, artificially made to resemble wood. A faked Anguissola painting is neither artificial not synthetic, IMO.

At least that's how the equivalent words work in Polish. "Sztuczny" ("artificial") implies fakeness on a chemical, material level. Exactly the same is true for "syntetyczny". Bogus authorship of a work is neither sztuczne nor syntetyczne. It is fałszywe (false).

If English does it differently, as Sam described, fine, I guess I have to accept it, but it still *feels* very wrong in my Polish head.

@Jane Wheelaghan
Tag in this case is a price tag.  And a STICKER is what the price tag on automobiles is often referred to as. (And possibly other items. ) So if the the price on the sticker is outrageously and/or unexpectedly high, you might have STICKER SHOCK.

@Jane Wheelaghan

Yes, same as STETHOscope.  And a prefix meaning chest, not used together with "chest."

STICKER SHOCK comes from the large window stickers on new cars, listing the total price, and itemizing it all, based on the base price, the add-ons, and various fees.  Maybe they don't do it the same way in the UK?

We don't say LASH UP for a wild party.  Actually, we don't say LASH UP for anything.  I think the sense here is when you tie things to the top of your car or donkey to transport more than is normal.

In the US, there's something called The Common Application that works the same way, although not all universities and colleges participate.  Still, you include "reach schools" and "safety schools."

In bowling, the pins are numbered from front to back.  The frontmost one is the 1 pin; the second row is the 2 and 3, left to right. Third row, 4, 5 and 6, and fourth row, 7 through 10.  I bowled once in a while as a younger person, but never got particularly good, so I stopped.

@Jim I don’t know but here’s my theory. I think that early crossword editors noticed that certain puzzles were more enjoyable, interesting and/or clever to solve. They identified the characteristics of those puzzles and began to establish criteria, such as no two letter words and the clue and the answer should not contain the same word. Taken to an extreme, you could have a clue like [One who bakes] solve to BAKER. I realize that’s a stretch but the idea is that the clue should not give away too much about the answer.
